Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2012 08:06PM maiyen wrote: Hi worriedhusband, I just wanted to comment that I recently found a large mass that did not feel as if it was moveable, quite firm, and more as if the skin just slides over it as you've described.  Mine ended up being a pretty decent size with a posterior chest wall location...it also was benign.  I'm still waiting to receive the pathology report so I can't tell you exactly what it says (they were thinking fibroadenoma or phyllodes tumor prior to biopsy), but I thought that I would share my experience.  Good thoughts to you both...I will be hoping for benign results for your wife.

Posts.Title: 43 and Diagnosed This Morning maiyen Mquara

Posts.Content: maiyen wrote: I had a pretty good idea that the core biopsy results were going to come back malignant as the radiologist gave me hints without straight up telling me, but anticipating and actually receiving a cancer diagnosis is still shocking. I don't know anything other than the mass that was biopsied is IDC and the suspicious lymph node biopsy came back benign. I'm supposed to learn more this afternoon when I meet with my doctor to go over my path report. My mom passed away from BC several years ago and the physicians at that time royally screwed things up with her so I'm overly cautious with my own health. Is it wrong to want to see someone other than who my doctor recommends - so far she's given me names for surgeons, but shouldn't I see an oncologist first? Is an NCI designated cancer center overkill since I've been told that my cancer has been caught early (my mom was told the same thing and then diagnosed as terminal a year later). I don't want to seem as if I'm paranoid, but I want to be able to sleep at night knowing that I'm seeing a great team of specialists (and how do you even find this great team?). Posts.Content: May 9, 2012 03:31PM maiyen wrote: You could always give them a call to see if they have the results yet.  Might save you a couple of days waiting for snail mail (if they were sent).  I know it's torture waiting, but trying to figure it all out now is pretty much useless.  Try and do some things that you enjoy to get your mind on something else.  Even if it is just temporary.

Posts.Content: May 16, 2018 10:59AM maiyen wrote: Thank you all for sharing your thoughts...and hugs back to you. Mquara, sorry to hear of your mom's passing. My mom was diagnosed at an early stage when she was 55, at 56 she was diagnosed at stage IV and given 6 months to live and then passed 7 months later. It is hard not to think of the experiences that our moms went through as we go embark on our own. I had a pointless afternoon appointment with my OBGYN who told me over the phone that she had details from the path report, which she preferred to provide in person, but she really didn't have as the results are still pending. I kind of felt like she just wanted to bill me for a doctor's visit and take advantage of the appt so she could try to refer me to her husband who is a surgeon. I did mention the possibility of wanting to travel to see a specialist and she said that IDC was so common that it wasn't necessary and if it was her, she would stay in Austin for treatment. So thank you for making me feel like I'm not overreacting.

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2013 08:22AM maiyen wrote: Very good topic OP, and great info on here so far!  I have been going back and forth on whether my next follow-up should include an MRI.  My BS recommended that I start doing MRIs in addition to US/mammos because I have heterogenously dense breasts, am high risk, and being monitored for two lumps.  I was wondering if an MRI would be overkill for someone my age (I'm 38), but the info on here is def food for thought...
Posts.Title: Breast density alrz1980 farmerlucy

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2013 11:31AM maiyen wrote: Beesie, you are right that the whole dense issue is pretty confusing and can be somewhat misleading. When I first started having breast issues, I wanted to try and educate myself on everything that I could and came across areyoudense and other various websites about density and many times I saw the connection between dense breasts and MRIs, but there was nothing about age being a factor, how dense breasts in younger women would not be considered unusual, etc. I have been having annual mammos with US every 6 months, but this last visit showed growth via mammo and virtually no growth via US. My BS said that US is typically more accurate when it comes to measuring, but I don't think she liked the fact that there was a decent amount of discrepancy between the two. And she had brought up the high risk, and with everything else...I think she decided that MRI would be best. When my BS first recommended an MRI, I expressed concern that insurance would not cover it and she explained that because of my dense breasts and high risk factors...it probably would (and should). And then when I contacted my insurance and learned what their specific guidelines are in order for MRI breast screenings to be covered, it all made sense. But in all honesty, if I didn't have my own personal experience with insurance and my BS...I would have probably assumed that I should get an MRI just because I have dense breasts. Jessica749, as far as why I am monitoring the lumps rather than removal...that is actually kind of under debate right now. The facility that I go to right now has explained to me that their surgeons are very conservative and unless there is definite cancer, they will not remove lumps and I'd have to seek an outside surgeon for that. I'm being monitored because my large lump is about 5 cm and they don't feel comfortable letting me go on the basis that the core biopsy had a benign finding and such little tissue was tested vs the majority of the mass which was not. I've heard from others to leave it in, take it out, get a second opinion...it is driving me nuts. And I really don't want to pay for an MRI only to have turn around and get an excisional biopsy because someone decides that it needs to be removed.
Posts.Title: Breast density alrz1980 farmerlucy

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2012 01:33PM maiyen wrote: Hi gillianinnh, My path report in April came back with PASH and as it's already been noted, it is benign but there is not much out there about it or there are conflicting treatments.  I am currently on a 2 year watch and wait plan with 6 month follow ups to monitor the stability of my large mass (I also have a small lump, but it hasn't been biopsied).  My BS seems ok with this treatment, but I have read from several sources online, including Johns Hopkins Ask An Expert program, that recommends excisional biopsy for PASH.  I'm not sure why the difference of opinion?  My mass is 4.6 cm x 4.7 cm and I have asked if the entire tumor is PASH or just some of the cells, but we don't know since I've only had a core biopsy.   I'm sorry that I don't have more info for you since I'm kind of in limbo about what to do myself.  However, I would recommend checking out the Johns Hopkins site and reading some of their breast Q&A, you might find some things about PASH over there.  You can even ask your own question and one of their breast specialists will answer it.  Lillie Shockney oversees that program.   Please keep us updated...would love to know what you decide!
Posts.Title: PASH - Pseudoangiomatous stromal hyperplasia gillianinnh djmammo

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2013 09:32PM maiyen wrote: Hi all, Just wanted to say that my initial biopsy came back as PASH and yes, I often feel discomfort in that breast.  It is intermittent pain and does not seem to be cyclical, but varies between sharp, zingy, achy, and 'pinchy' pain.  PASH can grow and how fast it might grow can vary (rare tumoral PASH seems to grow quite fast and can get very large).  I am actually having my mass removed at the recommendation of my surgical oncologist.  There has been some growth, and although not by a large amount, my mass is already 5 cm so we don't really want to sit around and have to take out even more tissue if it does keep growing.  Plus I am feeling the pain/discomfort. Take care.
Posts.Title: PASH - Pseudoangiomatous stromal hyperplasia gillianinnh djmammo

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2013 06:58PM maiyen wrote: Grace, I will keep you posted...hope you do the same :)  I think you have to do what is best for you, and I certainly understand how these follow ups don't help the anxiety.   Agnes...LOL  I started calling mine The Angry Boob because it always seemed to be grumpy and cause pain.  Now with surgery coming up, Angry Boob is being called by its new name, Frankenboob (not to offend anybody who has had any type of breast surgery).  I'm just trying to lighten up my mood and for some reason giving it a goofy name helps some.

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2012 02:17PM maiyen wrote: salie, I'm not sure if you've always had pain due to the lump or if started after the biopsy, but I had very sharp needle-like pain following my biopsy and a seroma was seen via mammogram about a month after the procedure.  I still have some pains even though the seroma is gone, but it's more of an achy/random stabbing pain.  I have't found anything that helps and I take birth control pills so I wouldn't be able to recommend that just for this symptom.  When I spoke to my BS about the pain she said that it is difficult to say what could be causing the pain...the lump itself, surrounding breast tissue, a nerve, etc?  I can't say anything about caffeine because I have avoided it for years.  I have heard of taking evening primrose oil as a natural supplement for breast pain, but I have not tried this.   Sorry if this isn't very helpful, but just my experience.  Hope you feel better soon and congrats on the B9 result!

I did ask a question to John's Hopkins 'ask an expert' and they responded in pretty much the same way that you did. They also said that they like to see Ki-67 less than 15% so that may play a factor in regards to chemo. Posts.Content: maiyen wrote: I had a mammotome biopsy on 4/13 and was told by the surgeon that she would call me within 24-48 hours to give me the results.  Three days after the procedure I was getting really anxious since I should have heard something by then so I called the office to ask about it.  I received a call back from a PA I think, that said my results were benign and everything was great.  When I asked about specifics (what kind of tumor it is, were there any red flags at all, etc) she said that she didn't know.  I asked if I could get a copy of the pathology report faxed to me and she said that she couldn't do that since they hadn't received the report yet.  I then explained that at the time of my initial consultation, the surgeon had recommended an excisional biopsy no matter what so I was just kind of antsy to move on to the next step already.  She said that she'd leave a message for the surgeon to call me (this was on 4/18).  I called the office on 4/20 to make sure that I wasn't supposed to call them since I hadn't heard anything.  The surgeon was still unavailable at that time so I left another message. I don't want to seem annoying or impatient, but is this pretty typical for the follow-up?  I've also been reading that after a core needle biopsy, a titanium clip should be inserted and a mammogram should be done to ensure that the correct spot was sampled.  I didn't receive a clip or a mammogram...does this affect anything? Sorry for all the questions, just a little stumped right now.  Thank you all.  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Biopsy follow-up questions maiyen Fergy

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2012 12:03AM - edited Apr 19, 2012 12:11AM by maiyen Hi Shachar, I just had a US guided vacuum assisted core biopsy on Friday and it was pretty pain free.  Please stay away from the horror stories online (and youtube)...they will just add to your fears.  I was scared to death and expressed this to the surgeon so she walked me through each step of the procedure while it was being done.  I was told that the only pain that I would feel would be a pinch and some stinging during the lidocaine and she was right.  She made sure that I didn't feel any sharpness when she started the incision (which I didn't).  And like the others, I felt some pressure when the device was actually inside which was kind of disturbing mentally just because I was thinking about that thing in my breast, but I didn't feel pain.  For my procedure, samples were taken via vacuum so there was definitely some noise and a sensation of slight 'chewing', but again there was no pain.  My lump showed on US to be 4.7cm, but the surgeon is wondering if it's closer to 6 cm.  It's at 12:00 (also left breast) and located on the posterior chest wall.  I drove myself home and also wore a sports bra 24/7 for the first 2 or 3 days.  I still have some occasional discomfort, but I think it has more to do with the location of the mass being so far back.   Good luck, it will be much easier than you think!
Posts.Title: U/S guided core needle biopsy? Shachar Shachar
